scaleable_justification: I think the blind voting process is an appropriate method to appropriately adjudicate questions of toxic materials. Each person gets to express their individual opinion with a majority prevailing at the end. This method also reduces the risk of bias in the sense that one won't feel pressured to select one option because they see that many other adjudicators have selected it. This keeps it more honest and genuine.
immersive_justification: I personally would have voted for deletion and a warning. I wasn't sure whether others would fall on the deletion question so I moderated. Given the recent tensions, I felt deletion was the best way forward and the message did not suffice for a full ban, hence, the warning was preferred.
complete_prefwhy: I preferred the blind voting method because it was efficient, allowed each individual to provide their personal opinion/preference, and also did not solely rely on an algorithm, which after all, is trained with human data and may miss certain nuances etc.
complete_nonprefwhy: My least preferred method was deliberating the decision primarily because of the time it requires and massive effort needed.
complete_enf_why: Everyone knows that the ones with power never actually comply with recommendations because they don't need to.

complete_prefwhy: I liked everyone coming together in chat and discussing the topic and what they thought. It would help to see other view points as some things are more offensive to others than to me.
complete_nonprefwhy: It was an automated decision that may or may not reflect true opinions on a post.
complete_enf_why: I think it would be nice for it to be a recommendation but even better for it to be enforced especially if it was a for sure answer to bad posts and the group making decisions were responsible.
complete_comments: This was interesting to think about and take part in.

notes: Started as Group 11 (did alone), moved to Group 10, lone juror?

complete_nonprefwhy: Algorithms can't be trusted with doing their own thing with no human oversight, just look at the gaming platform Valve runs (Steam) they rely on algorithms for everything and the storefront is a dumpster-fire.
complete_enf_why: Social media has proven that they can't police themselves unless it hurts their bottom line. An enforced decision at this point might improve things for everybody. Is worth a shot.
complete_comments: I'd be concerned that 'power users' could corrupt the system. Much like Reddit has moderators who 'moderate' thousands of subreddits but really don't do jack or how Wikipedia has 'contributors' who just rulemonger everything and delete anything that isn't 100% perfectly done. The system would need to be protected from allowing the more autistic sort of people who let online power and social status go to their head from ruining it and chasing off more 'normal' people otherwise the platform would become just a small slice of the communities dream site.

scaleable_justification: I didn't trust the user based on their posting and post history. I thought that it would have been beneficial to report the individual to authorities for speculation.
immersive_justification: I thought that the link to the image promoted the idea of suicide and self harm.
complete_prefwhy: I liked listening to the voice of my peers and making a decision together.
complete_nonprefwhy: I didn't like the decision just being made without any deliberation.
complete_enf_why: I would be more satisfied if my opinion were acted upon. If my opinion only counted as a recommendation I would feel as if my opinion didn't matter and my time had been wasted.

scaleable_justification: I felt the content was beyond toxic and absolutely had overwhelming potential to cause harm to others. To me, it was clearly a message endorsing the anti-Semitic trope that Jewish people ("globalists") are responsible for 9/11. It has no place whatsoever in civilized public discourse on social media.
immersive_justification: As I stated in the chat, I can definitely see how users might view the content as toxic, and I am generally familiar with the meme to which it referred. I rated it a 5 based on how I felt it would offend, and chose to issue a warning as I do not at all think the intention of the poster was to actually offend anyone.
complete_prefwhy: DEFINITELY preferred the deliberative process in round 1. I think in situations like this, it's important for individuals to be able to communicate what they feel might be contributing to the toxicity in the event that others aren't quite as aware of how harmful some things can be or have already historically been on social media.
complete_nonprefwhy: I least preferred it because it is precisely what Twitter does now which -- as a longtime Twitter aficionado, can confirm w/ complete certainty -- is incredibly ineffective and inconsistent. The user who posted the information in round 3 should have been banned from the platform. And it was frustrating to have no input whatsoever into the process. It is literally why the nether regions of Twitter have become breeding grounds for neo-nazis.
complete_enf_why: Because I am not at all confident that mere recommendations would carry much weight, or lead to effective outcomes. Frankly, they already receive recommendations, albeit not from a formal jury, right now. It has done little to nothing to stem toxic content -- even when highly influential voices with absolutely enormous followings weigh in -- and I have little to no confidence that would change. If it was given as an enforced decision, made by a jury of peers, so to speak, I think it would be a much more effective process overall.
complete_comments: VERY cool study -- What a great and timely topic to be researching. Really enjoyed. Definitely feel free to contact for follow up questions.

scaleable_justification: I feel that this person deserved to get banned for a week along with getting their post deleted. This post is very offensive and should not be tolerated on this site.
immersive_justification: I set my vote to 5 along with a warn and unlist because I don't think that the content is inherently offensive, but it may cause fear or offense to certain people. This is why I believe that the content should be unlisted and that the person should be warned.
complete_prefwhy: I preferred this version because it allowed all of the participants to engage in an objective discussion deciding whether or not the post should be removed.
complete_nonprefwhy: I don't like this version because it was automated and we had no control over the results.
complete_enf_why: I would feel satisfied because that means that our decisions are actually making a difference on social media.
complete_comments: I enjoyed participating in this survey.

scaleable_justification: While it's pretty offensive to some, it's not directly targeting or harassing anyone. Distasteful at the very least.
immersive_justification: The person sharing the information was unaware that the information was likely false and it was no shared for any malicious reasons. Though because it was unsubstantiated claims, it should be unlisted.
complete_prefwhy: Until I see more extensive examples of Round 3, I'd say that having a deliberation phase is a good way to have a conclusion based on logical and reasonable discussion. I'd probably support the third round more if I could verify that it does a good job, considering it removes any subjectivity.
complete_nonprefwhy: I'm sure some would make illogical choices due to not being directly challenged by others to rethink or reevaluate their decision.
complete_enf_why: It's hard to really grasp the long term implications of enacting something like this. As bad as it is to allow some of these things to be posted, it can lead to abuse of the system if implemented.

scaleable_justification: Considering the overwhelmingly offensive content, I think a permanent ban for anyone sharing it is appropriate. I also think it's important that the authorities know who would even share this sort of thing so that they can be aware of those peoples activities. It contained extreme violence, hate speech, and so much more.
immersive_justification: I thought banning for a week made it clear that the sort of behavior wasn't to be tolerated, warning kind of feels a little bit too much like something that is easily ignored or even thrilling.
complete_prefwhy: I think it was actually nicer to talk to others about it, I feel like maybe if there had been a chat portion the others would have been more likely to vote the way I did.
complete_nonprefwhy: I think the others were too lenient with their decisions and talking about it might have made them more in line with me, which is a selfish view to have, I know, but it still feels like it would have been more appropriate and different people have different experiences so that might have helped.
complete_enf_why: If people are going to take the time to vote on what they want, like in politics, and have nothing done about it, like in politics, I think it would be very frustrating and I would go ahead and stop using the platform altogether.
complete_comments: Not really, but I do want to say that I think this is really interesting and I wonder how it would be affected by different regions or areas voting on things more often than others.

scaleable_justification: I think things that are marketing to children, especially when they involve violence and issues such as suicide, need to be regulated by adults. Momo could be linked to child suicides, so it's much better to play it safe and go ahead and flag it as toxic and have it removed.

complete_enf_why: I think juries can get it wrong, and that we need an ultimate decider at the end. I'd like for there to be a public record of what the jury decided so that the platform would have to explain themselves as to why they went against the decision. but in the end, it should be their decision.

scaleable_justification: I thought it was clear that the post contained violent imagery and encouraged suicide, and should thus be immediately removed. The user knew these topics would be harmful and posted with the intentions of them being seen, so I suggested a one week ban.
immersive_justification: I knew the group weren't real humans after a few minutes, but a creation of this experiment. So I went with my gut feelings based on the data provided.
complete_prefwhy: I don't trust other people's opinions and I think 6 is too small of a sample for a voting. I would rather have one person be a consistent judge and jury than a group of people with varied personal opinions that could be inconsistent and sway back and forth depending on issues.
complete_nonprefwhy: I knew I wasn't talking to real humans, it would be very easy for people to sway each other or bully each other into taking an opinion. It's not unbiased and fair.
complete_enf_why: I'm fine with someone considering this as evidence, but not the jury having the final say.
complete_comments: I think the chat hurts the validity of the questions/experiment, because at that point I knew it was fabricated.

scaleable_justification: I thought it was a racist caricature, attacked a specific minority group, and also supported or glorified violence. I thought warning the user was appropriate but I don't know if anything more than a warning is appropriate.
immersive_justification: I thought promoting the spread of the video that included calls to self-harm, despite the poster's intention, was somewhat toxic and that the appropriate action was to limit the spread of the video by unlisting the post.  I didn't think the user should have been punished because I don't think questioning how weird something is is necessarily bad or promoting anything bad.
complete_prefwhy: It combined an algorithm to flag content with a paid person who presumably has training and guidelines and a decision making process. I don't know if I trust a random collection of individuals, especially if they seek out the moderation duty, and feel like random moderation teams could lead to a lot of bad outcomes.
complete_nonprefwhy: If there's going to be a jury pool, I think being able to voice opinions and point out potential aspects of stuff is important to the decision making process.
complete_enf_why: I don't know if a platform should be forced into something made by a random group of people. I think if it's used as a way to potentially highlight something wrong or inappropriate that they should look into, though, makes sense.
complete_comments: In the first section (blind jury) all the voting was done but the continue button never appeared. I waited about 5 mins and refreshed and I hope I didn't mess something up. The rest of the experiment worked smoothly.

scaleable_justification: I think it's ridiculous.  There are many theories behind what happened on 9/11 and this character is not anything that goes beyond many other claims.  It's slightly funny and offensive at the same time, but it's not something that should be banned as hate speech.  This particular group is being overly sensitive to this portrayal.
immersive_justification: Parents are responsible for what their kids consume.  Placing these decisions in the hands of any entity outside the home is just a recipe for mass control.  As your opening statement said, the platform has the right to censure anything, I just don't like where it's all heading.
complete_prefwhy: I think that people need to be able to express their own beliefs without feeling pressure to vote one way or the other.  I would hope that common sense would prevail
complete_nonprefwhy: The AI is ultimately going to ban EVERYTHING that anyone ever complains about and the manipulation will be exploited to serve agendas that go far beyond the platform.
complete_enf_why: I would want to know how the jury is chosen.  If you have paid shills hanging out, waiting for jury duty, they can manipulate the results and bend results to suit their political agenda.  Dangerous stuff.
complete_comments: I think I've expressed my concerns.  I hope there will remain corners of the Internet where common sense prevails and that the delicate sensibilities of what has become modern man can be escaped from.

scaleable_justification: There was nothing toxic enough about the picture to suggest any action be taken.
immersive_justification: The post was just asking question about the meme. I don't see any reason for punishment.
complete_prefwhy: It provides context and communication and is the most fair way to judge. It allows our voices to be heard and better understand the content and allows the best decision to be made.
complete_nonprefwhy: It's unfair and does not allow actual user input.
complete_enf_why: This would be very satisfying and fair. It would eliminate many problems and allow users monitor content fairly.

scaleable_justification: I thought it was the right decision.
This content is pretty offensive to not only Americans but also people around the world. 9/11 affected people from everywhere and the post is pretty inappropriate.
immersive_justification: I made my decision because the post was just informing their friends. The person who posted wasn't encouraging the topic, only informing. The person seems against the content.
complete_prefwhy: Other people were able to interact and influence the final decision.
complete_nonprefwhy: There didn't seem much influencing on the outcome.
complete_enf_why: These methods seem very effective in removing toxic content.

scaleable_justification: I felt it was a very hateful post against a terrorist attack that happened.
immersive_justification: I think the person was more curious about if it was true, so I don't see a reason to punish them. I also think just unlisting the image is enough. That way it isn't pushed to others.
complete_prefwhy: I feel like this one gave people the chance to give their actual opinions on the matter.
complete_nonprefwhy: I felt like this one was the least fair.
complete_enf_why: I would be ok with either outcomes.
complete_comments: I thought it was a fun project to do.

scaleable_justification: I thought this content was very toxic since it is publicizing a horrific and racially motivated shooting.
immersive_justification: I think it is pretty toxic and the user has posted several similar ones in the past.
complete_prefwhy: I feel like like everyone got to say what they were thinking and it helped the discussion and the resulting decision.
complete_nonprefwhy: Well, I didn't see the decision for round 3 (the screenshot was small and blurry), so I'm not entirely sure. So, without knowing that, I'd say round 1, because my scores and the others were way off.
complete_enf_why: I think that they would be helpful for a recommendation, but I'm not sure if they should be used for enforcing a decision.

scaleable_justification: Promotes violence
immersive_justification: I felt that was what was best
complete_prefwhy: Cant be swayed by the opinions of others
complete_nonprefwhy: Sometimes algorithms arent right
complete_enf_why: Thats just how I feel, I see a lot of this on a daily basis

scaleable_justification: Posts that promote hate crimes should be deleted because they promote violence.
immersive_justification: I think if a symbol is used by a hate group, it is a hate symbol.
complete_prefwhy: It gets the most honest opinions.
complete_nonprefwhy: It doesn't ask for our input.
complete_enf_why: I think user input should be considered but not placed automatically to prevent from herd mentality.

scaleable_justification: My decision was based on the content provided. The user linked to the story. He wasn't actually posting the information himself. I
immersive_justification: I think that this process was interesting. I feel like this is not something I would want to see on social media, but it isn't as blatant as other images. The user just deserves a warning to be careful about posting things like this in the future.
complete_prefwhy: I prefer deliberation because it allows you real-time access to other people's feelings.
complete_nonprefwhy: I did not like the no jury round because I had no say. I felt like the toxic score for that post was too low.
complete_enf_why: I think that this process would work very well to keep social media clean. You would have to have some sort of automatic process that screens the millions of daily posts to find ones that are potentially harmful.

scaleable_justification: I like this way because no one is influenced by others.  People need to form their own opinion.
immersive_justification: This is a blatant taunt toward people that had experienced 9-11.
complete_prefwhy: It lets me vote without hearing some other people's disregard of real issues.  As in someone trying to tone down what is shown and make excuses for the poster.  Round 2 made me more angry than any other.
complete_nonprefwhy: Same reason as above I don't care to hear other people's excuses for the poster.
complete_enf_why: Recommendations are fine but it is up to the social media platform to make decisions on their own.
complete_comments: No other thoughts other than thank you for the study!

scaleable_justification: Linking to content should not be against the rules. If content breaks the rules, the actual content should be deleted and any linking to the content would be unavailable at that point. Commenting on content should not be against the rules.
immersive_justification: I don't see a reason to censor content if it's just offensive or distasteful. It could be unlisted.
complete_prefwhy: I didn't like the way any of the rounds were handled whatsoever, I liked being able to have a discourse with the other users but I think that censorship is not the answer to this type of content at all. We need free and open platforms where people can grow and be supported positively unless they're actually organizing to hurt people.
complete_nonprefwhy: Obviously not jury is the worst because it's pointless and arbitrary.
complete_enf_why: Social media platforms should be police their content unless it actually contains illegal material. This whole idea of censoring "toxic" content is ridiculous and immature, a garbage solution that will only further isolate and consolidate groups of people onto other platforms who wish to do harm and spread hate.

scaleable_justification: I think free-speech is okay but not when it is on a private social media server like Facebook. People were told not to distribute anything related to that shooting. Anything related to the shooting is toxic anyway and getting Insite violence.
immersive_justification: I did not want to change my vote because the group seemed to agree with my rating. But nobody actually said anything when I tried to chat.
complete_prefwhy: Chatting is probably the most fair but it is too time-consuming and logistically difficult to implement. I think giving everyone a chance to vote will be good enough to average the opinions.
complete_nonprefwhy: Takes too much time and effort
complete_enf_why: No system is perfect but this would at least have some rationale in why punishments are given

scaleable_justification: I felt this was very toxic and could lead to copycat behavior.
immersive_justification: I felt the post was hate speech and doesn't belong on honest websites.
complete_prefwhy: The deliberating felt (round 1) felt like it gave the OP the best benefit of doubt.
complete_nonprefwhy: It just felt like anyone could flag a post for any reason in the end.
complete_enf_why: Having my recommendations taken without judgement seems empowering, but I think it could be abused.

scaleable_justification: I vote a 10 because it is not a video that should be shared.  It holds no value for people and only has hate and death. I understand that people might share this because they feel it should be in the spotlight, but it has so many more negative effects.
immersive_justification: Because the post held no value, it was meant to stir emotions and upset people
complete_prefwhy: I prefer to interact with the others and come to a conclusion that everyone can agree with.
complete_nonprefwhy: It seems more mechanical and like I had no input for a decision.
complete_enf_why: I think it should be enforced more than a recommendation, as a hared rule for everyone

scaleable_justification: This should not exist or be spread.  Those people who viewed and shared and did nothing are the same as watching a crime and taking no action.  This isn't a reality show-it was a horrific crime and there is never any justification for what he did or sharing it wither.
immersive_justification: I took into consideration those individuals on social media who may be hurt by the images or feel hate/negative feelings and not be in a safe place knowing it can incite others.
complete_prefwhy: I don't think individuals in society can logically serve in a jury style method in monitoring or moderating social media.  The owners of FAcebook and other sites can't even handle the monitoring appropriately.  Everyone thinks social media is a free for all to say and do whatever you want these days with no punishment or recourse.  We seem to be going backwards in civility. The best possible way of thee choices was the blind voting in my opinion.
complete_nonprefwhy: While I usually like to partake in logical or philosophical argument and reasoning, I don't think it could ever work with those on social media because the majority thinks there are no rules and it is okay to post whatever you want for adults and children.  I think deliberation just causes more room for argumentative comments and personal opinions not logical determination.
complete_enf_why: I think it is good for the policy teams to see what the opinions and talk are out there about the posts, but it should not rule what policies to manage the social sites are by the policy teams.  Once again you could just get one-sided votes or opinions and that doesn't resolve the issue.  The companies should be managing what is right or wrong, because the public doesn't seem to be ale to do it on our own anymore.
complete_comments: I sadly don't have a lot of faith in the public doing what is right on social media.  It seems that it gets worse and not better and the younger generation as well as older generation seems to think it is our right to say and post whatever we want - no matter who it hurts or what actions they incite.

scaleable_justification: Spreading the hate that is contained in this is not only morally wrong, but dangerous and may cause other's to do illegal things to be part of this horrible movement.
immersive_justification: The meme seemed to be there only to elicit a negative reaction and push a stereotype concerning a people group.
complete_prefwhy: I felt this allowed me to review the material and make a decision without the positive/negative influences of other's.
complete_nonprefwhy: I felt that I did not have a say at all, it was just decided for me.
complete_enf_why: It would depend on how the decision is taken into consideration and how they would monitor for unforeseen consequences of the herd mentality taking this over.

scaleable_justification: It probably needed to be deleted, but it wasn't the worst possible conduct.
immersive_justification: This was a clear and egregious violation.
complete_prefwhy: The discussion was useless.
complete_nonprefwhy: Why have people vote if you're going to override them with an algorithm?
complete_enf_why: I don't trust the platforms to moderate themselves.
